title: Usopp's Insecurity Foreshadows His Sogeking Transformation
summary: A theory that Usopp's deep insecurity and feelings of inadequacy revealed in Episode 235 directly foreshadow his adoption of the Sogeking persona, where he can be the brave warrior he wishes to be.
fullText: In Water 7, Usopp's insecurity about his weakness compared to the rest of the crew reaches a breaking point when he loses the money to the Franky Family. His subsequent conflict with Luffy isn't just about the Going Merry - it's about Usopp feeling that if the ship can be discarded, so can he. This emotional low point sets up his transformation into Sogeking, a completely fictional hero that others regard as 'real.' The symbolism is strong: Usopp's falsehoods creating his reality. Water 7 is the first major step of that notion, with some theorizing this may ultimately result in a mythical transformation, perhaps linked to a Devil Fruit like the imagined 'Human-Human Fruit, Model: Sogeking.'
author: Multiple One Piece theorists

title: The Going Merry's Spirit (Klabautermann) Was Aware of the Conflict
summary: A theory that the Going Merry's Klabautermann (ship spirit) was aware of and saddened by the conflict between Luffy and Usopp, with some fans believing the ship 'cried' during this episode.
fullText: A Klabautermann is a ship spirit that appears when a vessel is well-cared for and loved by its crew. The Going Merry's spirit had already manifested earlier in Skypiea when Usopp saw it repairing the ship. Fans theorize that during Episode 235, the ship's spirit was aware of the conflict tearing apart its crew. Some believe Usopp's deep love and care for the Merry - stronger than any other crew member's - is what allowed the Klabautermann to manifest. His willingness to fight Luffy for the ship represents the ultimate expression of this love. The theory suggests that Usopp's special connection to the Going Merry allowed him to sense its spirit and understand that the ship had feelings and deserved to be treated with dignity, not abandoned.

title: Luffy's Decision Represents His Growth as a True Leader
summary: A theory that Luffy's difficult decision to abandon the Going Merry despite his emotional attachment represents a crucial moment of growth, showing he can make unpopular but necessary decisions as a captain.
fullText: Throughout the early parts of One Piece, Luffy often makes decisions based on emotion and instinct. However, in Episode 235, he demonstrates true leadership by accepting the harsh reality that the Going Merry cannot be saved, even though it breaks his heart. This moment is theorized to be intentionally parallel to future decisions Luffy must make as he grows into a leader worthy of becoming Pirate King. The pain he feels, evident in his face when telling Usopp the ship is dying, shows he understands the weight of leadership - that sometimes a captain must hurt those he cares about for the greater good. Some theorists believe this moment foreshadows later difficult decisions Luffy must make regarding crew safety versus personal desires.

title: The Going Merry Conflict Mirrors Real-World Ship Traditions
summary: A theory that the emotional conflict over the Going Merry reflects real maritime traditions about the relationship between sailors and their vessels, treating ships as living beings with souls.
fullText: The Klabautermann legend is based on real German/Northern European maritime folklore about ship spirits. In these traditions, ships that are well-loved and maintained can develop a spirit that protects the crew. The conflict in Episode 235 mirrors real historical debates among sailors about when a ship should be retired versus repaired. Usopp's position represents the traditional sailor's view that ships are living beings deserving of respect and dignity, not just tools to be discarded. Luffy's practical decision represents the modern, pragmatic approach. This cultural clash is theorized to be intentional by Oda, showing the tension between honoring traditions and accepting harsh realities. Some fans believe this also connects to Japanese concepts of 'tsukumogami' - objects that gain souls after 100 years - though the Going Merry is much younger, its spirit emerged from intense love and care.
